Public finance understandings suggest that the building of a long-term asset used by the public ought to be financed initially by debt - so current people don't bear all the burdens when many people in the future actually get the benefits too - so borrowing/debt is used so the costs of paying the debt off is shared across the time period. I think you can recognize that your analysis is faulty if you put yourself in the position of a guy buying bonds. You make it sound like all government securities are inflation protected, but according to the WSJ, as of May this year, these only represented 8% of US debt - the rest is not indexed to inflation. So the question is, if you were buying bonds and you thought inflation was about to take off, why would you buy non-inflation indexed bonds at just a couple percent interest? That's what investors ranging from municipal pension funds to sovereign wealth funds have been doing. So clearly as Dr. Krugman says, the preponderance of the financial community is not anticipating high inflation anytime soon, and the record since 2008 says that they haven't been expecting it for a long time.

But the fact that they ARE fleeing stocks says that they are concerned about the ability of the market to consume the products that companies are making. That's a sign that they think that consumers don't have enough money, which means we ought to be thinking of ways to relieve this problem.

You make two errors when you say the following about inflation-indexed bonds:

" .... markets are practically begging governments to borrow and spend, say on infrastructure; interest rates on index bonds are barely above zero, so that financing for roads, bridges, and sewers would be almost free."

First, markets are definitely not begging governments to borrow and spend. Rather markets are implicitly saying that governments ARE GOING to borrow and spend and this "Keynesian" spending will further lower the natural rate of interest; and this, in turn, will cause term interest rates to fall even lower than they are at present. Rates fall when unconstrained governments borrow in their own currencies for wasteful spending. Look at Japan's all-time low rates and all-time high deficits for prima facie evidence of this phenomenon.

Second, the fact that inflation-indexed bonds carry minimal yields in no way makes them "almost free". They still have to pay out inflation. Now inflation has been dormant for a long time, and it may well stay dormant. But, as Cliff Asness of AQR recently wrote about your inflationary views, there is a difference between a prediction and a risk of something.

Perhaps the last line of today's column is best applicable to yourself:

"For the truth is that when people talk about what markets demand, what they’re really doing is trying to bully us into doing what they themselves want."

respectfully yours,

Nick

For god's sake, Denise -- phones are not new. My great-grandmother knew how to use a telephone.

But until the last 7 years or so -- since the smart phone -- phones were just phones. You talked on them. Now they are little computers with games and Facebook -- two things we know are quite addictive. You can shop on your phone, and watch videos and movies, and listen to music.

It's so intriguing that even affluent people do this, and even the poorest Americans on welfare manage to have iPhones. It's an incredible change in human society and in just 7 years! so we don't know the impact yet, and people have not even started measuring it.

I see people of all income levels talking on the phone while driving, and while ignoring the pleas of their children ("mommy mommy mommy MOMMY!"). I think some of these people would text their friends through a nuclear explosion. Nothing gets their attention when they are "immersed".

They do it while driving. A couple years ago, my car was totaled and I was nearly killed, when a driver (who was texting on her phone!) drove through a red light at an intersection. She didn't even slow down! she was so engrossed in TYPING while she DROVE.

Do you think that woman talked much to her baby -- the one in the car seat in the back of her car? I doubt that.

Although several people agree with you opinion, it contains several unsupported accusations and omissions of fact.

To start with, it was not cheap money, it was investors money, and it was supposed to be paid back with interest.
Your characterization of those in the financial services industry is specious. A few of them engaged in actions that were as close to being unsavory as they could get, but the majority were just plain hard working brokers and agents serving their clients honorably.

My broker is a decent hones man, who gives me the best advice has has available, and there are many thousands like him.

No one from Wall Street "bullied" me to buy or sell some equity, I was given the opportunity to do so, and told the risks.

Most of the big firms were responsible for businesses being able to start up, or add to the business, by providing funding to do so, and that money came from people like me.

Further more, you are equivocating the financial market, with the production market. The investors are those who provide the financing for ventures, and the firms that provide that money, have a fiduciary duty to their investors, to use it in their best interest.

As for the stock buybacks, again you show an ignorance of the financial system. It is the companies that issued those stocks that buy them back, not the Wall Street firms. Wall Street underwrites the issuance of the stock, they sell it for the company,after that is belongs to the buyers.

" I seriously doubt whether the kinds of vicious threats against Ms. Sarkeesian would ever be made by people who had not indulged in a steady diet of video games."

I have to disagree with this. The roots of misogyny go far deeper. Video games as a form of alienated-male bonding are just one manifestation.

(please note I am only referring to whatever subset of gamers likes to wallow in overt misogyny.)

Gamer Gate thinly veils its disgust toward women and feminism under the guise of "ethics" in the gaming industry. It's hard to defend a group, no matter how loosely connected, that largely targets women and any minor voice supporting women in games. It deals in manufactured contretemps, such as the Quinn debacle.

Sarkeesian pointed out tropes that gamers have pointed out for years in gently mocking tones. These jokes were small quips about the differences between males and females in games as well as anime. For example, one could joke about the trope of male characters being decked out in armor while females are largely fighting in their underwear in some titles, or the suggestive poses of females versus the males.

We shouldn't forget that before Gamer Gate, Sarkeesian and her supporters were also targeted by people who largely don't understand the terms "feminism" or "social justice." It's terribly disappointing that in an age where more and more Americans are attending college that we're so largely uneducated. Pointing out that some Gamer Gate supporters were targeted too doesn't mitigate that fact - it only shows the toxicity of this discussion.

When Roger Ebert claimed video games can never be art, or if games are relegated to the status of children's toys, us gamers often push back. We speak of G.T.A., less of a "murder simulator" and more of the game equivalent of the Godfather, or that gamers are largely adults. It's ironic, then, that we act so much like children.
